o: The primary command-line interface (CLI) for interacting with PostgreSQL

q: psql command to connect to a database?
psql command to describe a table schema?

o: Binary JSON format. Parsed/Processed (slower) on input, but very fast to query/index.
Exact copy of input text (preserves whitespace). Faster to insert, slower to query. No indexing.

q: Which is recommended: JSON or JSONB?
o: JSONB (for almost all use cases requiring querying/indexing)

q: Operator to check if Array contains value?

o: Key-Value store within a column (Pre-dates JSONB, text-based)
Pseudo-type creating an auto-increment integer using a SEQUENCE object implicitly
SQL Standard auto-increment (GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY). Preferred over SERIAL.
Configuration determining which schemas are searched for non-qualified table names
Multi-Version Concurrency Control. Readers don't block Writers. Each sees snapshot.
Process reclaiming storage occupied by dead tuples (deleted/updated rows)
UPDATE/DELETE marks rows as dead (doesn't remove). New inserts use new space. Vacuum frees dead space.
Background daemon automatically triggering VACUUM based on threshold of dead tuples
Transaction ID (XID) that inserted the row version
Transaction ID (XID) that deleted (or updated) the row version. 0 if alive.
The Oversized-Attribute Storage Technique. Compresses/Stores large columns off-table.
Typically when row exceeds 2KB (Postgres page size is 8KB)
Main configuration file (Memory, Ports, Logging, Workers)
Host Based Authentication. Controls client authentication (IP, Database, User, Method).
Allows connection without password (Insecure for production, ok for local)
Leverages OS user identity (Unix socket). User 'postgres' OS user = 'postgres' DB user.
Location on file system where database objects can be stored (Mapping to Disk)
View showing current connections, queries, states, and pids

q: How to cancel a running query (without killing connection)?

o: Returns data from modified rows (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE) in one round trip
Deletes rows and returns their contents (like a Select)
WITH clause. Named temporary result set. Postgres materializes them (historically, though changed in v12).
Data type representing a range of values (e.g. [1, 10)). Native overlap support.
Overlap operator (Do these two ranges/arrays have common elements?)
Shows execution plan for a query
Executes query (Actual run) and shows plan with actual timing/rows
Fast bulk loader/exporter (Server side). \copy is client side.
Command line utility to backup (export) a database into script or archive
Generalized Inverted Index. Best for JSONB, Arrays, and Full Text Search.
Generalized Search Tree. Good for Geometric data (PostGIS), Ranges, Network addresses.
Block Range Index. Very small, stores min/max per block range. Great for huge, naturally sorted time-series data.
Index with a WHERE clause (e.g. WHERE active = true). Smaller and faster.
CREATE INDEX idx ON tbl USING GIN (json_col);
Operator class for GIN indexes optimizing @> operator (Smaller/Faster than default, but supports fewer operators)

q: What starts a Transaction in Postgres?
How to see transaction isolation level?

o: Read Committed (Readers see only committed data)
Write-Ahead Logging. Ensures durability (ACID). Changes logged before writing data pages.
Process flushing dirty pages from Shared Buffers to Disk and truncating WAL
Memory config dedicated to Postgres for caching data pages (Recommended ~25% of RAM)
Yes, heavily relies on OS Filesystem Cache (Double buffering happens, but OS cache is vital)
Memory limit *per operation* (Sort/Hash) within a query. Too low = Disk Spill. Too high = OOM.
Memory for maintenance ops (VACUUM, INDEX CREATE). Usually set higher than work_mem.
Lightweight connection pooler for PostgreSQL (Reduces connection overhead)
Supports thousands of client connections mapping to few server connections (Pooling)
Physical replication shipping WAL records to Standby server (Exact copy)
Replica that accept Read-Only queries while applying WAL updates
Replicating data objects/changes (decoded from WAL) allowing partial/cross-version replication

q: Publisher / Subscriber model is used in?

o: Mechanism on Primary ensuring WAL segments needed by Replica are not deleted
WAL files accumulate indefinitely -> Disk Full -> Server Down
PARTITION BY RANGE/LIST/HASH. Splitting table into child tables managed automatically.
Partition Pruning (Query ignores irrelevant partitions) and maintenance (Detach old data)
Procedural Language for PostgreSQL (Variables, Loops, Conditions)
Used to quote string bodies (e.g. Function body) avoiding need to escape single quotes
Executes an anonymous code block (PL/pgSQL) without creating a function
BEFORE: Can modify NEW row before insert. AFTER: Sees final state, good for audit/cascading.

q: Trigger: FOR EACH ROW vs STATEMENT?
o: ROW: Fires once per row (e.g. 10 times for 10 inserts). STATEMENT: Fires once per query.
Records representing the new state (Insert/Update) and old state (Update/Delete) of the row
Constraint ensuring no two rows overlap (e.g. Booking time ranges). Requires index.
INSERT ... ON CONFLICT (col) DO UPDATE ... (or DO NOTHING)
Table not written to WAL. Faster writes. Truncated on crash recovery (Data loss).
Pub/Sub mechanism for asynchronous events between sessions/clients
Application-defined lock (using ID). Database doesn't enforce on rows, App must check it.
Like a Correlated Subquery loop in JOIN form. Right side references Left side columns.
Exploring arrays, calling set-returning functions per row (e.g. TOP N per category)
Standard interface to access remote data (Postgres, CSV, MySQL) as local tables (postgres_fdw)
Extension tracking execution statistics of all SQL statements (Count, Mean Time, I/O)
View showing current locks held by transactions
System catalog table containing relation metadata (Tables, Indexes, Sequences)
System catalog table containing data types
System hidden column used as internal PK for system tables (Legacy)
Aggregates values into a String with delimiter (like GROUP_CONCAT)
Provides Trigram Matching (breaking strings into 3-char chunks) for fuzzy search and similarity
Sorted list of distinct lexemes (normalized words) for Full Text Search
Search query representation (e.g. 'fat & rat') with boolean operators

q: Function to convert text to tsvector?

o: Calculates relevance score of a document against a query (for sorting)
Spatial database extender for PostgreSQL (Geometry, Geography types)
Feature where a table inherits columns from a parent table (Predecessor to Partitioning)
Rewrites query parse tree before planning (e.g. Implementing Views). Powerful but complex.
Rule rewrites the query sent to optimizer. Trigger executes function per row/stmt during execution.
Simple views (1 table, no Agg/Dist/Group) are auto-updatable. Complex views need INSTEAD OF Triggers/Rules.
RANGE BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND CURRENT ROW (Not whole partition!)
ROWS counts physical rows. RANGE looks at logical value range.
count(*) FILTER (WHERE type='A') - Cleaner syntax than CASE WHEN
CTE allowing self-reference (Union All) to traverse hierarchies/graphs
Postgres has CYCLE clause (v14+) or manual path tracking array check
Function (tablefunc extension) to Pivot rows to columns
Snapshotted result of query stored physically. Needs REFRESH.
REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW name (Locks table unless CONCURRENTLY used)
Requires Unique Index on the Materialized View
Fires on DDL events (CREATE/DROP TABLE). Global to DB.
Audit schema changes, prevent specific DROP commands
Facility to stream large files (Images) into pg_largeobject (oid based).
Bytea is single column (RAM limit ~1GB). LO supports streaming/seeking > 1GB.
Tool for in-place major version upgrade (Fast linking mode supported)
Uses hard links to reuse data files (Instant upgrade, no copy)
Copying completed WAL segments to secondary location (Backup/PITR)
Shell command executed to copy WAL file (e.g. cp %p /archive/%f)
Point-In-Time Recovery. Restore Base Backup + Replay WAL Archive to specific timestamp.
File presence indicates Postgres should start in Recovery Mode
File (standby.signal) indicating server is a hot standby replica
Action turning a Standby into Primary (Allowing writes)
Packaging for objects/C-libs. 'CREATE EXTENSION' loads into DB.
Extension for hashing (digest), encryption, and generating UUIDs (gen_random_uuid)
Generates v4 random UUID (native in v13+)
User-defined data type with constraints (e.g. type 'email' = text check(@ symbol))
Type representing a row structure (CREATE TYPE name AS (col1 int, col2 text))
Static set of ordered values (CREATE TYPE mood AS ENUM ('sad', 'ok', 'happy'))
Pre-allocating numbers in memory for performance. Risk of gaps on crash.
nextval increments. currval returns last value generated in THIS session.
Manually sets sequence current value (e.g. after bulk load)

q: What happens when Sequence reaches Max?

o: Not safe. Data truncated on restart.
Process of extracting changes from WAL into a clean format (e.g. JSON) for external systems
Popular Output Plugin for Logical Decoding (Outputs JSON stream)
Module transforming raw WAL data into specific format (JSON, ProtoBuf, SQL)
Set of tables on Publisher to be replicated (CREATE PUBLICATION name FOR TABLE...)
Configuration on Subscriber connecting to Publisher (CREATE SUBSCRIPTION ...)
No (Historically). Only DML (Insert/Update/Delete). Schema changes manual.
No. Sequences are not replicated logically. Careful sync needed.
Waiting for WAL flush to disk (on Primary and optionally Standby) before reporting Success
Disables waiting for WAL flush. Faster, but risk of data loss on crash.
Config on Primary listing Standbys that MUST ack write for Synchronous Replication
ANY 2 (s1, s2, s3) - Waits for any N standbys
% of page filled on Insert. Lower (e.g. 70-80) leaves room for HOT updates (Optimizing Vacuum).
Update where new row version stays on same page. Avoids Index updates. Crucial for performance.
No indexed columns modified + Space available on page (Fillfactor)
Threshold to force aggressive vacuum to prevent Transaction ID wraparound (Shutdown risk)
XIDs are 32-bit. Running out causes old data to become invisible. Must 'Freeze' old XIDs.
Mechanism for row locking sharing (Select For Share). Wraparound issue exists here too.
Stats for Background Writer process (Checkpoints, Buffers Cleaned)
Trickle flushes dirty pages to disk to reduce Checkpoint spike load
Role with all privileges (Bypasses checks). Default is 'postgres'.
Role used as a Group (cannot login directly)
Default template database. New databases are copied from this.
Extensions marked trusted can be installed by non-superusers
Inner query must be on Right side of Join
Row Level Security policies restricting access based on user role/variable
ALTER TABLE t ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
CREATE POLICY p ON t USING (user_id = current_user_id());
Role attribute allowing user to ignore RLS (Superuser has this)

q: What is 'Foreign Key' Action Set Null?
o: On Delete, sets child FK column to Null
Prevents deletion of parent if children exist (Default)

q: What is 'Advisory Lock' Session vs Transaction?
o: Session locks persist until unlocking or session end. Tx locks auto-release at commit.
Acquires session level exclusive advisory lock. Waits if busy.
Attempts to lock. Returns true/false immediately (Non-blocking).
Physical location pointer (Block Number, Offset). Syntax: ctid.
Pointer to result set allowing fetch row-by-row
Cursor that remains open after transaction commit (WITH HOLD)
Data type for cursor reference (passed to functions)
Parsed plan saved for reuse. PREPARE name(args) AS ... EXECUTE name.
Returns plan in JSON format (Easier for parsing/tools)
Shows Shared Hit/Read (Memory vs Disk) usage. Requires ANALYZE.
Measures time per node (Can add overhead). Default On.
Arbitrary units (Startup Cost .. Total Cost). 1.0 = Sequential Page Read.
Cost to fetch the first row (e.g. Index Seek = low, Sort = high/wait)
Estimated average byte width of rows output by the node
Tool to verify or enable/disable data checksums on an offline cluster
No. Requires cluster shutdown (pg_checksums --enable) on older versions. Newer allows initdb flag.
Dangerous tool to force a WAL reset (Last resort for corrupted transaction logs). Risk of data inconsistency.
Efficiently resynchronizes a demoted primary with the new primary (avoids full rebuild)
Using multiple background workers to execute a single query (Scan/Join/Aggregate) faster
Node that collects results from parallel workers
Maximum workers a single query/Gather node can use
Compiling parts of query execution ( Expressions, Deforming) into native machine code using LLVM
Complex, long-running analytical queries (OLAP). Overhead hurts short OLTP queries.
on/off. Enabled by default in modern Postgres.
Bulk imports table definitions from a remote server (via FDW) into local schema
Optimization sending WHERE clauses / Sorts to the remote server instead of filtering locally
Yes. postgres_fdw supports INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE on remote tables.
User defined aggregate function (CREATE AGGREGATE) using state transition functions
SFUNC (State Function), STYPE (State Type), FINALFUNC (Optional Finalizer)
Optimized window aggregates using MSFUNC (Inverse transition) to slide window efficiently
Pluggable interface allowing different storage engines (heap, zheap, columnar) per table (Postgres 12+)
System catalog storing information about table columns (attributes)
Tracks dependencies between objects (ensures you can't drop object if others depend on it)
DROP TABLE x CASCADE; Automatically drops dependent objects (Views, FKs)
plpython3u allows access to OS, Files, Sockets. Only Superusers can create functions.
Try SSL, fall back to plain text if unavailable (Insecure)
Generic Security Services API (often used for Kerberos authentication)
Using external Directory Service for user/password validation
User name mapping file (Maps OS/Ident/Cert user to Postgres Role)
Tool to take a binary physical backup (base backup) of a running cluster (for Replication/PITR)
Streams WAL logs needed for backup consistency during the backup (Self-contained)
Streams WAL logs in real-time to a local directory (Zero data loss capability)
Utility to check connection status of a PostgreSQL server
Benchmarking tool (TPC-B like) to stress test Postgres
Variables defined in psql (\set v value) used in scripts (:v)
Client-side COPY. Reads file from client machine and sends to server. (COPY is server-side)
psql command to toggle display of query execution time
Toggles expanded (vertical) output mode. Good for wide tables.
Re-executes the previous query every N seconds (\watch 2)
View showing contents of config files AND pending values (validation errors)
Provides access to runtime parameters (context, min/max, current val)
Client connection parameter. Visible in pg_stat_activity. Useful for debugging.
Aborts any statement taking longer than specific milliseconds
Time to wait for a lock before aborting. Use before strict DDL migrations.
Terminates sessions idling inside an open transaction (holding locks/vacuum) too long
They hold locks and prevent VACUUM from cleaning up dead tuples (Bloat)
Planner hint (NOT memory allocation) estimating OS cache + Buffer Pool. Helps prefer Index Scans.
Planner cost estimate for non-sequential disk page fetch. Lower for SSDs (1.1). Default 4.0 (HDD).
Extension to load relation data into Shared Buffers / OS Cache (Manual Warming)
Extension providing view to inspect contents of Shared Buffers (What pages are cached)
Extension to inspect Visibility Map (VM) and PD_ALL_VISIBLE flags
Bitmap tracking which pages contain only 'visible' tuples (All old XIDs). Enables Index-Only Scan.
Scanning index only (no heap fetch) if VM confirms all tuples on page are visible to snapshot
Fallback to heap read if VM says page is not all-visible (Dirty)
Leaves space in B-Tree pages (Default 90%). Lowering helps concurrent inserts/right-growth.
Index with non-key columns in leaf (Payload). CREATE INDEX ... INCLUDE (col).
Left-to-right. (a, b) supports query on (a) or (a,b). Not (b) alone (efficiently).
Scans index to build bitmap of TIDs, then reads Heap based on bitmap (Sorted physical IO)
If bitmap too big for work_mem, it degrades to tracking Pages instead of Rows (Re-check required)
Fastest access method. Retrieving row by known CTID (Block/Offset).
SELECT * FROM t, LATERAL func(t.col). Calls func for each row in t.
Function that returns NULL if any argument is NULL (Skipped execution). RETURNS NULL ON NULL INPUT.
Can modify DB or check time (random(), timeofday()). Optimizer cannot cache.
Returns same result for same args within a single table scan (current_timestamp). Can be used in Index Scan.
Returns same result for same args always (1+1). Computed at plan time. Required for Functional Index.
Function executes with privileges of the Author (Creator), not the Caller. (Like SUID).
Default. Function executes with privileges of the Caller.
Privilege Escalation if search_path is not secured (User can hijack calls)
Hints planner about expense (Default 100). High cost prevents running usually.
Estimate of rows returned by Set-Returning Function (Default 1000). Helps Join planning.
Functions accepting 'anyelement' or 'anyarray'. Logic works on multiple types.
Function accepting variable number of arguments (as an array)
Defines how a data type behaves with an index method (e.g. text_pattern_ops for LIKE)
Rules for string sort order and equality (locale dependent)
Byte-order sorting. Fastest. No locale rules.
Postgres 12+. Can define Case-Insensitive collation natively without CITEXT.
Schema containing system tables and built-in functions. Always in search_path (implicitly).
SQL Standard views of metadata (Portable). Maps to pg_catalog.
Catalog of cast paths (Type conversion functions)
Catalog of Access Methods (Index types: btree, gist, gin...)
Catalog of Roles/Users and Passwords (Sensitive, needs superuser)
View on Primary showing connected Standbys and their WAL lag/state
View on Standby showing status of WAL receiver process (connection to primary)
View showing active/inactive replication slots and retained LSN
Oldest Transaction ID needed by any active transaction/slot. Determines what Vacuum can clean.
Client creates new connection to send Cancel signal (SIGINT) to backend PID
Cancel (SIGINT) stops query but keeps connection. Terminate (SIGTERM) kills process/connection.
pg_ctl reload (or SELECT pg_reload_conf()). Doesn't disconnect existing sessions.
Maps external user names (Ident/Cert) to internal Postgres role names
OS feature (HugeTLB) reducing TLB misses for large Shared Memory (shared_buffers)
Sets the name visible in process title (ps aux). Good for multi-instance servers.
Emergency mode (postgres --single). stdin/stdout interface. Used for repair.
The main supervisor process (postgres) that spawns backends
Background process handling checkpoints (separately from bgwriter since v9.2)
Periodically flushes WAL buffer to disk (avoids commit wait)
Process aggregating stats (UDP). Writes to temp files/memory for views.
Process that starts Autovacuum Workers when needed
Conflict on Standby when WAL replay needs to act on an object (e.g. drop table) currently locked by a read-query
Max time Standby waits before cancelling running queries to allow WAL replay to proceed
When Vacuum on Primary cleans up old row versions needed by a long-running transaction on Standby
Enable 'hot_standby_feedback' (Tells Primary not to Vacuum rows needed by Standby)
Primary table bloat (Vacuum is delayed because Standby needs old rows)
Process of marking old tuples as 'Frozen' (Visible to all future transactions) to reset XID age
Minimum age (in XIDs) before a tuple is frozen. Prevents freezing too early (wasteful if row changes soon).
Vacuum that visits every page (skips Visibility Map optimization) to freeze tuples. Triggered by max age.
Rebuilds index without blocking writes (Postgres 12+). Uses more IO/CPU but keeps app live.
Provides functions to key exact tuple-level stats (e.g. dead_tuple_percent) to diagnose bloat
Wasted space in table/index files due to dead tuples not yet reused or freed
Partitioning based on hash of partition key (modulus/remainder). Distributes data evenly.
Partition catching all values that don't match other partitions (Catch-all)
Optimizer capability to skip scanning partitions that cannot contain the WHERE clause value
Event Trigger type firing before a DDL command executes
BEGIN ... EXCEPTION WHEN ... END. Catches errors. Has performance overhead (Subtransaction).
Retrieves info about last SQL command (e.g. ROW_COUNT affected)
Loop construct to iterate over an Array
Maps a local Postgres user to a remote server user/password
Increases histogram bucket count (default 100) for a specific column. Helps with bad cardinality estimates.
Captures cross-column correlation or N-Distinct values for group of columns
Statistic estimating number of unique values. Negative value means ratio (e.g. -1 = Unique).
Cost unit to process a row in CPU (Default 0.01). Reference for planner.
Cost unit to fetch a page sequentially from disk (Default 1.0)
Signal sent to Postgres to reload configuration files (without restart)
Signal used to Cancel the active query (Ctrl+C equivalent)
Signal used for Smart Shutdown (Wait for active sessions) or Terminate Backend
Force kill. Process halts immediately. Shared memory may be corrupted (Requires Auto-Recovery on start).
Stops new connections, waits for existing clients to disconnect, then stops.
Stops new connections, sends SIGTERM to active sessions (aborts transactions), saves state, stops.
Sends SIGQUIT. Aborts immediately without saving state. Like a crash. Recovery needed on start.
Postgres checks FK on Insert in Child (Read lock on Parent). Can cause blocking if Parent is widely updated.
On Delete/Update of Parent, Postgres must Scan Child table to check for orphans. Slow! Index FK columns.
View showing stats (seq_scan, idx_scan, n_tup_ins) for user tables
Indicates potential missing indexes (Lots of sequential scanning)
IO statistics (heap_blks_read vs heap_blks_hit) for user tables. Hit ratio calculation.
> 99% (Most pages found in buffer). If low, need more RAM or better queries.
-a. Dumps only data (INSERT/COPY), no DDL (CREATE TABLE).
-s. Dumps only DDL (Table definitions), no data.
Run restore in parallel (Multi-threaded). Only works with custom/directory format dumps.
Binary format. Compressed. Flexible (allows partial restore, reordering). Recommended.
Fraction of table size (0.2 = 20%) that must change to trigger autovacuum. Lower for huge tables.
Minimum number of tuple updates (50) to trigger vacuum. Used with scale_factor.
Memory for temporary tables (Session local). Default 8MB.
Time to wait before flushing WAL, hoping to group commit with others (Group Commit).
OS call forcing flush to physical disk. MUST be 'on' for durability. 'off' is risky (only for temp DBs).
Writes full page image to WAL on first change after checkpoint. Prevents 'Torn Page' corruption.
Partial write (e.g. 4KB of 8KB written) during crash. DB page is mixed old/new garbage.
Tool to benchmark easiest/fastest fsync method for specific hardware
Tool to decode/display raw WAL files (Debug/Forensics)
Function that reveals no info about arguments in error messages. Allowed in security barrier views/RLS.
View option preventing optimizer from pushing predicates down (leaking data) before view filter applies
Function to manually move a slot forward (skipping WAL). Dangerous but fixes stuck slots.
Typically 2KB chunks. Stored in separate toaster table.
pglz (default) or lz4 (v14+, faster). Compresses attributes before storage.
Extension for Time-Series data (Hypertables). Auto-partitioning by time.
Extension turning Postgres into a distributed database (Sharding tables across nodes)
Server connection assigned to client for entire session duration. Good for temp tables.
Server connection assigned only for transaction duration. Highest scale. No session features (SET, Temp Tables).
Server connection assigned per statement. Very restrictive (No multi-statement tx). Aggressive.
Hash identifying unique query structure (normalized). Stable across restarts (v14+).
Indicates what a process is waiting for (e.g. IO:DataFileRead, Lock:relation)
Internal memory locks (Spinlocks/Semaphores) protecting shared structures (Buffers, WAL)
Contention on Hash Map mapping pages to Shared Buffers (Hot pages)
Waiting for WAL buffer flush to disk (Commit latency)
Mechanism disabling cost-based delays if Wraparound is imminent (Emergency mode)
Unique ID generated at initdb. Ensures backups/WALs belong to same cluster.
Binary file containing cluster state (Checkpoint info, WAL position, State). Vital.
Tool to display pg_control file contents (Check DB state: shut down vs in production)
Stats on replica conflicts (snapshot, tablespace, lock) causing query cancels
Max space a process can use for temp files (Sort spills). Prevents disk fill execution.
Logs temporary file creation > size. (-1 disables, 0 logs all). Good for tuning work_mem.
Logs queries taking longer than N ms (Slow Query Log)
Logs when a session waits longer than deadlock_timeout for a lock
Time (default 1s) to wait before checking for deadlock condition (Expensive check)
Enables timing of block I/O calls. Essential for Explain (Buffers/Timing). Off by default.
Tracks execution stats (count, time) for user functions (pg_stat_user_functions)
View showing live progress of Vacuum (Phase, Heap Blks Scanned)
View showing live progress of Index Creation
View showing progress of COPY command (Bytes processed)
View showing simple LRU cache stats (CLOG, Subtrans, etc)
Bitmap storing transaction status (Committed/Aborted). Now usually called 'pg_xact'.
Directory containing Commit Log files (renamed from pg_clog in v10)
Directory containing symlinks to external Tablespaces
New signature allowing graceful wait before termination
If public is first, malicious user can create object masking system object. Put 'public' last.
Generated column syntax (Computed). 'STORED' calculates on write.
Validates XML structure. Provides xpath support.
Extracts data from XML using XPath query
MAC address (6 bytes). macaddr8 (8 bytes EUI-64).
Currency amount with fixed fractional precision (locale dependent). Often discouraged for numeric/decimal.
Lists files in a directory (Restricted to Superuser/pg_read_server_files)
Reads content of a file (text) from data directory
Log Sequence Number. 64-bit integer representing a position in the WAL stream (FileId / Offset).
Default 16MB. Can be changed at compile time or initdb (v11+).
Identifier preventing confusion between original history and recovery history (branched history after PITR/Promotion)
File ending in .partial. Remnant of the old timeline after a promotion/recovery.
Slot that is automatically dropped when the session ends. No risk of disk full if client crashes.
Lossy index structure (Signature). Good for multi-column queries where varying subsets of columns are queried.
Extension based on GIN. Stores additional info (positions/rank) to speed up FTS ranking and phrase search.
Feature (v13+) allowing Vacuum to use multiple workers for Index phases (Faster cleanup)
Adding a standard table as a partition to a partitioned table. (Requires scanning/validating constraints unless CHECK is present).
Attaches without exclusive lock on Parent (Postgres 14+ P), avoids blocking select/insert.
Removes table from partition hierarchy. Data remains in table (now standalone). Fast way to archive data.
Signals logging collector to switch to a new file immediately
Least restrictive lock. Taken by SELECT statements. Conflicts only with Access Exclusive.
Taken by UPDATE, DELETE, INSERT. Conflicts with Full/Scan locks.
Most restrictive. Conflicts with EVERYTHING (even Select). Taken by ALTER TABLE, DROP, TRUNCATE, VACUUM FULL.
Taken by VACUUM (standard), CREATE INDEX CONCURRENTLY, ANALYZE. Conflicts with itself.
Number of connection slots (default 3) reserved for Superusers. Allows Admin login even if max_connections reached.
Pristine system template database. Should never be modified. Used to create template1.
Permission to create/alter other roles (except Superusers)
Permission to connect in replication mode (streaming/logical) and manage slots
Forces a switch to a new WAL file (useful for archiving/backups)
Returns current write location in WAL
Creates a named point in WAL (e.g. 'before_upgrade') for PITR targeting
Returns all GUC parameters describing values and descriptions
Grand Unified Configuration. Term for Postgres configuration parameters.
Sets a config parameter only for the current transaction (Reverts on Commit/Rollback)
Resets all settable parameters to default values for the session
Stats about WAL archiving process (last_archived_wal, last_failed_wal)
Number of buffers written during checkpoints
Number of buffers written by the background writer (cleaning dirty pages)
Number of buffers written directly by backend (query) process. Bad! Means bgwriter/checkpointer is too slow.
Function listing files in pg_wal directory (access restricted)
Pauses WAL replay on standby (Useful for inspecting state at a point in time)
Timestamp of the last transaction replayed on Standby (Used to calculate Lag)
Returns PIDs of sessions blocking a Safe Snapshot export
Exporting a snapshot identifier so other transactions can see exactly the same state (Consistent backup)
Uses a synchronized snapshot (exported by another session) to dump consistent state
Returns the Process ID (PID) of the current session
Timestamp when configuration files were last loaded
Timestamp when the server instance started
Returns list of channels the current session is LISTENING to
Fraction of async notification queue currently occupied
Safe limit for stack usage (function recursion). Prevents crash (Segfault).
Returns array of PIDs blocking the specified PID
View showing allocations in shared memory (Buffer pool, Locks, WAL buffers)
Specifies password (Not recommended for security, use .pgpass)
Msut be 0600 (Read/Write by user only) on Unix. Ignored otherwise.
Server's private key. Must be protected (0600).
Formatting string for log lines (e.g. '%t [%p]: [%l-1] user=%u,db=%d ')
Controls which SQL statements are logged. Values: none, ddl, mod, all.
Logs data definition statements (CREATE, ALTER, DROP)
Logs ddl + data-modifying statements (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, TRUNCATE, COPY)

q: RLS Policy: USING vs WITH CHECK?
o: USING checks visibility (Select/Update/Delete existing). WITH CHECK checks new data (Insert/Update new).
Changing column type (e.g. text to int), Adding column with default (pre-v11), VACUUM FULL, CLUSTER.
Exclusive Lock on table. Copies all data to new file. High IO. Blocking.
Libraries to load at server start (pg_stat_statements, pgaudit). Requires Restart.
Libraries loaded at start of each session
Extension for detailed session/object audit logging (Compliance)
Extension running scheduled jobs (cron syntax) inside the database
Extension for managing partitioned tables (time/serial based automatic creation)
Third party tool to remove bloat (LIKE Vacuum Full) but ONLINE (Minimal locking)
Yes (tcp_keepalives_idle, etc). Helps detect dead client connections.
Configures allowed SSL cipher suites (Security hardening)
Configures hashing algorithm for CREATE/ALTER ROLE. Default scram-sha-256 (v14+).
Controls whether RLS policies are applied (on/off). Default on. Superusers bypass.
Minimum message level sent to client (NOTICE, WARNING, ERROR)
Minimum message level written to server log

q: Can Postgres be run as Root?
o: No. Security feature prevents running server as root user.
File in data directory containing PID and start info. Prevents multiple instances on same dir.
The list of expressions between SELECT and FROM
List of relations used in a query
Tree of nodes (Scan, Join, Sort) representing execution strategy
Component that recursively initializes, steps through, and shuts down plan nodes
Checks syntax and builds Parse Tree
Generates multiple path candidates and selects cheapest based on cost model
Extension allowing Oracle-style hints in comments (Postgres core doesn't support hints)
Belief that hints rot and disguise bugs. Fix the statistics or planner instead.
Plan created without parameter values (Costly if distribution is skewed)
Plan created for specific parameter values (Peeking). Used for first few executions.
After 5 executions, if Generic is not much worse than Custom average, switch to Generic (Avoids replanning)
Pre-warm loads data from disk to RAM. Cache is the RAM holding it.
View showing SSL status/cipher/bits for each connection
No. It is a 64-bit integer (fixed point). Input/Output is formatted string.
Not a Number. Supported by Postgres Numeric/Float types.
Postgres supports 'infinity' and '-infinity' for timestamp comparisons
Returns name of current schema in search path (usually first one)
Time taken from parsing to completion
Check pg_stat_user_tables for high sequential scans and usage patterns
